qas.question: According to Isabelle Stengers, what are unifying factors in diverse practices (like ecology and feminism) that have become interested in Whitehead's work?

answers.text: practices that unite political struggle and spirituality with the sciences of education

qas.question: In what areas of the world has interest in Whitehead's work spread in recent decades?
What other fields have shown more recent interest in Whitehead's work?

answers.text: ecology, physics, biology, education, economics, and psychology

qas.question: Who was one of the first theologians to try to interact with Whitehead's ideas?
What was the basis for "Nature, Man and God"?

plausible_answers.text: practices that unite political struggle and spirituality with the sciences of education

qas.question: According to Isabelle Stengers, what are non unifying factors in diverse practices (like ecology and feminism) that have become interested in Whitehead's work?
In what areas of the world has interest in Whitehead's work spread in past decades?

plausible_answers.text: ecology, physics, biology, education, economics, and psychology

qas.question: What other fields have shown less recent interest in Whitehead's work?
Who was one of the last theologians to try to interact with Whitehead's ideas?

context: Isabelle Stengers wrote that "Whiteheadians are recruited among both philosophers and theologians, and the palette has been enriched by practitioners from the most diverse horizons, from ecology to feminism, <a0_0><b5_0>practices that unite political struggle and spirituality with the sciences of education<b5_0/><a0_0/>." Indeed, in recent decades attention to Whitehead's work has become more widespread, with interest extending to intellectuals in <a1_0><b6_0>Europe and China<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and coming from such diverse fields as <a2_0><b7_0>ecology, physics, biology, education, economics, and psychology<b7_0/><a2_0/>. One of the first theologians to attempt to interact with Whitehead's thought was the future Archbishop of Canterbury, <a3_0><b8_0>William Temple<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In <a4_0>Temple's Gifford Lectures of 1932-1934<a4_0/> (subsequently published as "Nature, Man and God"), Whitehead is one of a number of philosophers of the emergent evolution approach Temple interacts with. However, it was not until the 1970s and 1980s that Whitehead's thought drew much attention outside of a small group of philosophers and theologians, primarily Americans, and even today he is not considered especially influential outside of relatively specialized circles.
